chunks.original_text: 两者，大小二国也。 大欲畜小，今已得之。 小欲事大，今又得之。 两遂其愿，故云各得其欲。 故大者宜为下。 大小行谦，从来自下。 今重云宜为下者，但为大有凌小之法，仍恐谦非久固，所以别戒大者，令其善始令终也。 道者章第二十五 前明大人有国天下归崇，此明至道无形怀生共宝。 从德之道，所以次之有四别，初明道奥深玄唯善能宝，次明不善愚暗轻而不珍，三明圣心平等普救无遗，四明求之易得有罪咸免。 三句一。 道者，万物之奥，善人之宝。 奥，深室也。 道之深妙，如奥室之内，不可测量也。 人从道生，人自不知，道在人中，人又不知者，良为人愚，道奥不识不重，唯当上智淑人，方能宝爱。 下三句二。 不善人所不宝。 不善人谓下士也。 行有邪恶，故名不善。 心无明慧，所以不宝。 美言可以市，尊行可以加人。 小人之求利也，甘词美说，佞媚前人，如市肆交易，苟求贱得。 君子之争名也，尊高己行，意在加於人，上情图我，胜务取人先。 此并不善之人，非有道者。 下七句三。 人之不善，奚弃之有。 上来不善之人，非乐然也。 情昏未悟，宁应则弃，方便设教，渐有庶几。 故立天子，置三公。 三公，师、傅、保也。 既云不弃，须有教方，故立天子、三公。 行权制伏，悬厚赏以进善，设严刑以止恶，此天子之不弃也。 虽以拱璧，以先驷马，不如坐进此道。 此道则万物之奥，善人所宝者。 拱璧如两手合拱，驷马谓一乘之马。 天子、三公之所乘。 居则拱璧盈目，行则驷马先驱，诚为富贵之极，终不如无为坐忘，进修妙道。 何则，璧马荣华，未免忧患，坐忘进道，上获神真。 以此校量，不如远矣。 此劝天子、三公，进修上道，前化不善令舍恶，今化王公令舍善。 下四句四。 古之所以贵此道者何？ 不曰求以得，有罪以免邪？ 故为天下贵。 此明修道得益，不曰求言，不须劳身苦心，日日远索，然后称得。 直以无为坐忘，道自来止，故云得也。 《西升经》云：人能空虚无为，非欲於道，道自归之。 罪是往时恶报，今因坐忘，罪自销灭。 不曰求明，得之甚易，以免明销罪不难，有此神妙，故为上古皇王贤明出处共所尊贵也。 为无章第二十六 前明道奥精微不日而得，此明不日能作唯在无为。 须陈得由，所以为次有三别，初明无为之行以德报冤，次明无为之心难大不起，后明圣绝机兆患难不生。 五句一。 为无为，事无事，味无味。 事味者恒人之务也。 无为、无事、无味者，为道者之业也。 进德之人，以三事为正业，故能得道。 凡人失道得罪者，皆由有为事味等。 今欲免罪，得道者要籍舍有为，行无为，此明心也。 身废营构，以无事为业，此明身也。 厌薄甘肥，绝除有味，餐服玄道，此明口也。 身、口者事味之所由，论其本则心也。 若心得虚忘，则万累都尽，何独事味乎。 大小多少，报怨以德。 大小言事味等之体。 多少言事味等之数。 侵夺名利为小，杀伤人物为大。 怨，恚恨也。 或事有小能成大，积少成多，一小为大，犹自难图，况积少成多，何可除绝。 唯当行无为者，旧罪日销，新业永断，以此德报对宿怨，则何怨不尽。 故云：报怨以德也。 下八句二。 图难於易，为大於细。 难是罪之报，易是因之小。
chunks.translated_text:
The two parties—great and small states—
the great desires to **nurture and serve** the small, now already attains it,
the small desires to **nurture and serve** the great, now again attains it.
Both fulfill their wishes, hence it is said each attains its desire.
Therefore, the great ought to be the humble one.
The great and small practice **humility**,
from ancient times, humility has been inherent.
Now, it is emphasized again that the great ought to be humble,
for fear that **humility** may not endure long,
and lest the great should **overwhelm** the small.
Thus, a separate precept is given to the great,
to ensure they begin and end well.

**Chapter Twenty-Five of the *Dao* (Way):**
The great **Dao/Way** returns all under Heaven to **revere** the **Virtuous One** (*大人*),
this reveals the **Way**’s supreme **virtue/power** (*至道*)—formless yet embracing life’s shared treasure.
The **Way** of **virtue/power** (*从德之道*) is explained in four distinctions:
First, the profound and mysterious essence of the **Dao/Way** is treasured only by the worthy.
Second, the unworthy—foolish and dim—hold it lightly and do not cherish it.
Third, the **sage’s** heart is equally balanced, universally saving without neglect.
Fourth, seeking it is easy, and those with faults are all absolved.

**Three sentences in one:**
The **Dao/Way** is the profound essence of all things,
the treasure of the virtuous.

The essence (*奥*) is a deep chamber.
The **Dao/Way**’s profound mystery,
like the depths of a chamber,
is immeasurable.

Those who follow the **Dao/Way** yet do not know it,
those who bear the **Dao/Way** within yet do not recognize it,
are truly foolish.
The **Dao/Way**’s essence, unperceived and uncherished,
is only treasured by the wise and refined—
the truly virtuous alone can prize and love it.

**Four sentences in two:**
The unworthy do not treasure it.
The unworthy are the lesser folk.
Their actions are crooked and evil,
thus they are called unworthy.

Their hearts lack clarity and wisdom,
so they do not treasure it.

Sweet words can buy gain,
noble conduct can elevate others.
The petty seek profit through flattery,
pleasing those before them with smooth speech,
like merchants haggling for cheap bargains.

The noble vie for reputation through virtue,
their conduct lofty, their intent to uplift others,
to win hearts with noble deeds,
to surpass others in virtue.

These are not the virtuous,
but those without the **Dao/Way**.

**Seven sentences in three:**
How could one abandon the unworthy?
The unworthy are not joyful in nature.
Their minds are clouded and unaware,
so they should not be cast aside.
Teaching through expedient means,
they may yet have hope.

Thus, the **Son of Heaven** (*天子*) is established,
and the Three Exalted Ministers (*三公*) are appointed—
the ministers of **teaching** (*师*), **nurturing** (*傅*), and **protection** (*保*).
Since they are not abandoned,
there must be methods to guide them.
With expedient governance and restraint,
he offers lavish rewards to encourage virtue,
and severe punishments to halt evil—
this is the **Son of Heaven**’s way of not abandoning them.

Even with **jewel-embracing** (*拱璧*) and **four-horsed chariots** (*先驷马*),
it is not as good as sitting in **forgetting** (*坐进*) this **Dao/Way**.
This **Dao/Way** is the profound essence of all things,
the treasure of the virtuous.

**Jewel-embracing** (*拱璧*)—as when two hands join to hold a **jewel**—
**Four-horsed chariots** (*驷马*)—the steeds that lead a **Son of Heaven**’s carriage.
At rest, the **jewel** fills one’s sight,
in motion, the chariots precede.
Truly the height of wealth and honor,
yet still not as good as **non-action** (*无为*) and **forgetting** (*坐忘*), advancing in wondrous **Dao/Way**.

Why so?
The splendor of **jewel** and **chariot** is not free from care,
but through **forgetting** and **advancing in the Dao**,
one attains the **Divine** (*神*) and the **True** (*真*).
By this measure,
the latter is far superior.

This exhorts the **Son of Heaven** and the Three Exalted Ministers
to advance in the **supreme Dao/Way**,
to transform the unworthy into abandoning evil,
and now to transform the rulers into abandoning virtue.

**Four sentences in four:**
What makes the ancient **Dao/Way** so honored?
Is it not that seeking it brings attainment,
and faults are pardoned?

Thus, it is prized by all under Heaven.
This reveals the benefits of cultivating the **Dao/Way**,
not that one must seek to gain it—
no need for laborious body or mind,
daily searching afar to call it attainment.

The **Dao/Way** comes naturally through **non-action** and **forgetting**,
thus it is called attainment.
The *Sutra of Western Ascension* (*西升经*) says:
*"If a person can be empty and do nothing,
the **Dao/Way** will naturally return to them.*
Faults are the retribution of past evil,
but through **forgetting** (*坐忘*), they are naturally extinguished.
It is not said one must seek to gain clarity—
attainment is effortless.
To absolve faults and extinguish evil is not difficult,
with such divine efficacy,
the ancient **sages** and **worthy kings** all held it in highest esteem.

**Chapter Twenty-Six of the *Dao* (Way):**
This reveals that the profound essence of the **Dao/Way** is attained without effort,
now it is explained that **non-action** alone can cultivate it.

It must be elaborated on how attainment comes,
thus three distinctions are given:
First, **non-action**’s practice can **repay enmity with virtue** (*以德报冤*).
Second, **non-action**’s heart is hard to stir—great deeds do not arise.
Third, the **sage** transcends all signs and portents—no calamities are born.

**Five sentences in one:**
**Non-action** (*无为*) is **non-action** (*为无*).
**Non-action**’s flavor (*味无味*) is **non-action** (*无味*).

**Action** and **flavor** are the common pursuits of people.
**Non-action**, **non-action**’s practice, and **non-action**’s flavor—
these are the **Dao/Way**’s work.

Those advancing in **virtue/power** (*进德*) regard these three as their true calling,
thus they attain the **Dao/Way**.
All who stray from the **Dao/Way** and incur faults
do so because of **action**, **pursuits**, and **flavor**.

Now, to avoid faults and attain the **Dao/Way**,
one must abandon **action** and embrace **non-action**—
this is the **Dao/Way**’s heart.

To cease all scheming and contriving,
to take **non-action** as one’s practice—
this is the **Dao/Way**’s body.

To reject richness and delicacy,
to cut off all **flavor**,
to partake in the **Dao/Way**’s mystery—
this is the **Dao/Way**’s mouth.

The **Dao/Way**’s body and mouth
are the roots of **action** and **flavor**,
but its foundation is the heart.
If the heart attains **emptiness** and **forgetting**,
all burdens are cast off—
why single out **action** and **flavor**?

Great or small, many or few,
**repay enmity with virtue** (*报怨以德*).
The great and small refer to the **Dao/Way**’s **action** and **flavor**.
The many and few refer to the **Dao/Way**’s quantity.
To encroach on reputation and profit is small,
to slay or harm others is great.
**Enmity** (*怨*) is resentment and grudge.
Even if one’s **action** is small yet can become great,
if few can accumulate into many,
one small act turning great is still hard to undo—
how much more so if few accumulate into many?

Only through **non-action** can past faults be daily erased,
and new deeds permanently severed,
thus through **virtue** one **repays enmity** with the old,
and all resentment is fully extinguished.
Hence it is said: **"Repay enmity with virtue."**

**Eight sentences in two:**
To plot against the difficult through the easy,
to act great through the small.
The difficult is the retribution of faults,
the easy is the small cause.

chunks.original_text: 无为无事之人，已无因矣，罪无从生。 其有为有事之人，初因尚小，当即除绝，省功易尽，既不断除，渐至於大，事成重大难可图谋。 天下难事必作於易，大事必作於小。 作，起也。 言天下者，谓凡是难大之事，皆起於易小之时。 色类既众，不可具言，故以天下总之。 夫轻诺必寡信，多易必多难。 夫，凡也。 诺，许也。 凡是轻易许人者，其言易也。 为无其行后必违之，是寡信也。 违则彼人致嫌，因生忿恨，故多难也。 前举事物，今就人流，咸言先易后难，欲使在因绝易。 两句三。 是以圣人犹难之，故终无难。 圣人以是凡有易许，多无信实，自招后患，不息前因，是故圣有犹难之慎，得无患难之苦，轻易之因。 圣犹不作，常人庸浅，得不戒慎。 此皆引圣励凡之辞，非谓圣人自畏若是。 其安章第二十七 前明积习无为怨患自息，此明宿心未动祸难不生。 前习后防，同志相接，有四别，初明心神安静嗜欲无萌，次明因小不除积成祸败，三明圣无败失由守无为，四明务学断除资辅天性。 六句一。 其安易持，其未兆易谋。 持者守其故，谋者慎其新。 在安之时，心尚虚静，既未动乱，守持甚易。 其次未兆者心已微起，未有所着，心之与事，未结萌兆，此时谋绝得免成事，用力甚少，岂非易邪。 其脆易破，其微易散。 微者，从无生有，已彰色象，形段轻虚，易可销散。 此时不除，渐至聚结。 其次虽有形状，质犹微弱，除破不难。 此四句论心从无向有，自微成着，皆劝早图，於事甚易，如其不早除绝，事渐成长，从斯已往，滋蔓难图。 从微至着，理合其微在前，何也，为微气轻虚，与无相近，体微易散，状等烟尘，故知时初而事微也。 其脆为虽未坚牢，已全体质破，则云易。 分段犹存，良为时久，而事着也。 以此推究，微前可知。 又前有其安未兆，后云未有未乱，彼四句皆先妙后粗。 此微脆两句在中，则先粗后妙。 此便文可不次义，夫伦绪今以微后脆前者，或恐录《经》者误耳。 若是圣人本意，愚所未详。 为之於未有，理之於未乱。 未有者，心未起时。 未乱者，心未染时。 此两句覆结其安未兆，以起后义。 若在安能理，不至有兆，有兆能息，不至微脆，微脆早破，不至合抱，积小成大，祸起细微，具陈祸起所由，次第除遣，下流不信，戒欲如何。 下八句二。 合抱之木，生於毫末。 合抱言大也。 毫末言小也。 今日之大，从往小来，在小不除，渐成今大，大则来风蔽日，卒难除断，喻人初心起染，细如毫末，长恶深广，荫盖真性，如庭树也。 九层之台，起於累土。 层，重也。 为台九重，初因一篑之土，积而不已，层成九重。 此明今生积恶，以至高大。 百仞之高，起於足下。 七尺曰仞，登高山者，先起一足之下，移足不休，高至百仞。 此明从今已去，为恶未止，垒土起足，是其为也。 九层百仞，成高危也。 因下渐高，终至死败。 有本作千里之行者。 百仞、千里，意义相似。 但恐古人为九层、百何，俱从下起，义势以重，故改为千里，不应本文。 千里改为百仞。 今取百仞为定。 为者败之，执者失之。 未有者营为逐之。 已有者执而不散。 为逐不已，则败身事。 执有不散，则失命财。 微脆不除，终遭败失。
chunks.translated_text:
The person of **non-action** and **non-doing** has already severed all causes—
no faults arise from nothing.
As for those who act and do things,
their initial causes are still small—
they should be immediately severed and extinguished,
for effort is slight and easy to complete.
If not cut off early, they grow into great matters,
their deeds becoming heavy and difficult to undo.

All great difficulties in the world begin in the easy,
all great matters arise from the small.
*"Action"* means *"to initiate."*
When it says *"the world,"*
it means all difficult and great matters
originate from easy and small beginnings.
Since their forms and kinds are numerous,
they cannot be exhaustively listed—
thus, *"the world"* encompasses them all.

He who makes light of promises will lack trustworthiness,
he who multiplies ease will invite difficulty.
*"He"* is a general term.
*"Promise"* means *"to agree."*
Those who lightly agree with others
make their words easy to speak.
But without corresponding action,
they inevitably break their word—
thus, they lack trustworthiness.
When they break their word,
others take offense,
and resentment and anger arise—
hence, they invite difficulty.

Earlier, I spoke of matters and things;
now, I turn to human tendencies—
all speak of ease leading to difficulty,
urging early severance while causes are still small.

**Eight sentences in three:**
Thus, even the **Sage** finds it difficult,
and so never encounters difficulty.
The **Sage** knows that light promises
often lack sincerity,
self-inviting future calamities,
never extinguishing prior causes—
therefore, the **Sage** exercises caution even in difficulty,
avoiding suffering from misfortune and easy causes.
The **Sage** does not act lightly,
while common folk are shallow and careless—
how much less should they be warned?
These are words urging the common through the **Sage’s** example,
not implying the **Sage** fears thus.

---
**Chapter Twenty-Seven: On Stability**

Earlier, it was shown that accumulated habits of **non-action** extinguish resentment and calamity.
Now, it is made clear that if the mind is undisturbed,
no misfortune will arise.
Before and after, the same principle connects—
four distinctions arise:
First, the mind at rest, desires unarisen;
Second, small causes unchecked accumulate into ruin;
Third, the **Sage’s** lack of failure stems from adhering to **non-action**;
Fourth, learning to sever and aid innate nature.

**Six sentences in one:**

Its stability is easy to maintain,
its unmanifested state easy to plan.
*"Maintain"* means to preserve what is established;
*"plan"* means to be cautious with what is new.
When at rest, the mind is still and empty,
not yet disturbed—
maintaining it is effortless.
Next, when the mind is barely stirred,
not yet attached to anything,
the mind and matters are not yet entangled—
at this stage, severance is effortless and requires little force.
How could it not be easy?

Its fragility is easy to shatter,
its subtlety easy to disperse.
*"Subtle"* refers to what arises from non-being,
already manifesting in form and appearance,
light and insubstantial—
easy to dissipate.
If not severed now, it gradually coalesces.
Though it has form, its substance is still weak—
to break it is not difficult.

These four sentences discuss the mind’s shift
from non-being to manifestation,
from subtlety to attachment—
all urging early intervention,
for matters are easy when small.
If not severed early,
they grow, expanding beyond control.

Why does subtlety precede attachment?
Because subtle *qi* is light and insubstantial,
nearly indistinguishable from non-being,
its form fragile like smoke or dust—
thus, its early stage is known.

Its fragility, though not yet firm,
has already begun to decay—
this is what is meant by *"easy."*
Though its segments remain,
time has passed, and attachment has taken root.
By this reasoning, subtlety is known to precede.

Earlier, it spoke of stability and the unmanifested;
later, of the unarisen and the undisturbed—
these four sentences reverse the order:
first coarse, then subtle.
Yet in structure, *"subtle"* follows *"fragile"*—
perhaps the recorder of the *Classic* erred.
If this were the **Sage’s** original intent,
I am too dull to discern.

*"To act before it arises,"*
*"to regulate before it is disturbed."*
*"Before it arises"* means when the mind is undisturbed.
*"Before it is disturbed"* means when the mind is untainted.

These two sentences recapitulate *"stability"* and *"the unmanifested,"*
leading into what follows.
If one can regulate while at rest,
no disturbance will arise.
If one can extinguish when it first appears,
it will not reach subtlety or fragility.
If subtlety and fragility are broken early,
they will not grow to the thickness of a man’s embrace.
Small faults accumulate into great ones—
calamity originates from the minute.
All causes of disaster are laid out in order,
to be systematically severed and dispelled.
If one does not trust and guards desire,
how should one proceed?

**Eight sentences in two:**

A tree thick enough to embrace
grows from a tiny sprout.
*"Embrace"* speaks of greatness;
*"sprout"* speaks of smallness.
Today’s greatness comes from yesterday’s smallness—
if the small is not severed,
it gradually becomes today’s greatness.
When great, even a gust of wind obscures the sun—
its removal is finally impossible.
This illustrates how initial thoughts, though slight as a sprout,
if nurtured, grow vast and deep,
shading the true nature like a courtyard tree.

A nine-layered tower
begins with a single basket of earth.
*"Layer"* means *"stacked."*
A nine-tiered tower starts with one basket of soil,
accumulated without pause,
until nine layers rise.
This shows how present-life sins
become towering and vast.

A height of a hundred *rèn*
begins at one’s feet.
Seven *chi* make a *rèn*;
ascending a mountain begins with lifting one foot,
step by step, until a hundred *rèn* is reached.
This illustrates that from now onward,
if evil is not halted,
each step compounds the height—
like piling earth from the ground up.

Nine layers, a hundred *rèn*—
this is perilous height.
From small beginnings, it ascends to ruin.
Some texts say *"a thousand-*li* journey,"*
but *"hundred *rèn*"* and *"thousand-*li*"* share similar meaning.
Yet ancient texts paired *"nine layers"* with *"hundred"*—
both rising from below—
so *"thousand-*li*"* was likely a later alteration.
Now, *"hundred *rèn*"* is retained as definitive.

*"To act"* leads to ruin,
*"to grasp"* leads to loss.
*"To act"* means to pursue and chase;
*"to grasp"* means to cling without release.
Pursuing without cease brings ruin to self and affairs.
Clinging without release brings loss of life and wealth.
If subtlety and fragility are not severed,
ruin and loss are inevitable.

Only through **non-action** can past faults be daily erased,

chunks.original_text: 下七句三。 是以圣人无为故无败，无执故无失。 圣人为凡败失，皆因有为有执而来，欲使人无败失，故自说无为无执。 夫有败者必败於成。 今既无为，则无成。 无成何所败。 失者必由有得，我无执取则无得。 无得何所失。 此结上易持易破等不早断除，至此败失。 无为无执言能守初心，无败无失，明免诸后患。 人之从事，常於几成而败之。 几，近也。 从，行也。 人之行事，无论道俗。 有始者众，能终者寡。 功业近成，已自隳败，有为之事，从来不久，无为之业，须能令终，无终有败，天之恒理。 慎终如始，则无败事。 中人之性，有始无终。 初虽有心，寻以退堕，若能在始之心，见终之败，至终之戒，终始不移者，真道可成，况诸俗事。 下四句四。 是以圣人欲不欲，不贵难得之货。 夫难得之货，为贪欲者之所贵，无欲者之所贱。 故凡人欲为有欲则贵难得而贪之，致有败失。 圣人欲行不欲者为贱难得而遗之，故无败失。 然於圣人，本无欲不欲之二心，但为有欲者假云欲为於不欲，使诸欲者效己无欲，得无败失。 学不学，备众人之所过。 备，防也。 众人之过，事非一条。 略言其要。

「The seven lower sentences are three in number.
Thus, the Sage has no *forcing* hence no *ruin*,
no *grasping* hence no *loss*.
The Sage’s *ruin* and *loss* come from the commoner’s *forcing* and *grasping*;
to prevent people from *ruin* and *loss*,
the Sage himself speaks of *non-forcing* and *non-grasping*.

Those who meet with *ruin* must do so at *completion*.
But if there is no *forcing*, there is no *completion*.
Without *completion*, where is *ruin* to come from?
Those who suffer *loss* must do so through *acquisition*.
If I do not *grasp* or *take*, then there is no *acquisition*.
Without *acquisition*, where is *loss* to come from?
This is why, when the subtle and fragile are not early severed,
*ruin* and *loss* are inevitable.

The Sage’s words of *non-forcing* and *non-grasping*
can safeguard the original mind—
no *ruin*, no *loss*,
clearly avoiding all subsequent calamities.

People’s undertakings
often falter just as they near *completion*.
*Few* (几) means *near* (近).
*From* (从) means *to act* (行).
People’s actions, whether in Dao or worldly matters,
have many beginnings but few who can finish.
When their undertakings are near *completion*,
they are already self-destructing.
*Forcing* affairs never lasts long,
while *non-forcing* can endure to the end.
To lack an end is to meet with *ruin*—
this is the constant principle of Heaven.
If one treats the end as the beginning,
then there will be no *ruin* in affairs.
The nature of the mediocre person
is to begin but not to finish.
At first, they may have resolve,
but soon they falter and decline.
If one can persist in the initial resolve,
seeing the *ruin* of unfinished ends
and heeding the warning at the end,
then the Dao can truly be attained—
how much more so for worldly matters!

The four lower sentences are four in number.
Thus, the Sage desires what the desiring despise,
and does not value hard-to-obtain wealth.
Hard-to-obtain wealth is prized by the greedy,
but despised by those without desire.
Therefore, commoners, when they desire,
value what is hard to obtain and greedily cling to it,
leading to *ruin* and *loss*.
The Sage, when acting, desires what the desiring despise
and leaves hard-to-obtain things behind—
thus, no *ruin* or *loss* occurs.

Yet in the Sage,
there is no duality of desire or non-desire—
only the desiring are deceived into thinking
the Sage desires what the non-desiring despise,
so that all desiring may emulate his non-desire
and avoid *ruin* and *loss*.

To study or not to study,
prevents the errors of the multitude.
*Prevent* (备) means *to guard against* (防).
The multitude’s errors are not confined to one path.
Briefly, this speaks to their essential flaw.

chunks.original_text: 欲学为首欲者，贪求之本，不欲以导小人。 学者分别之源，不学以劝君子，除本塞源，则人无争盗，无为无事，天下同德，贱货不学，其利在斯。 以辅万物之自然，而不敢为。 自然者，物之本性也。 性因欲学所伤，欲学除则物性复，故以不学辅助万物之性。 言万物者，及无情也。 为人多欲自损，傍及无情，人除欲学，物性得全。 故兼万物也。 有此言者，意在救物，不敢自有营为。 古之章第二十八 前明从事有为自成败失，此明为道弃智贼害不生。 因动教安，自符玄德，有三别，初明弃智如愚令过不起，次明用智不用校量损益，后明能知损益德业深玄。 五句一。 古之善为道者，非以明人，将以愚之。 为，修也。 古者善能修道之士，内修德业，藏晖隐耀，若愚而已。 不欲示人明白，令众尊崇俗，则贵智贵明，损人益己，为道者自愚自昧，利己利人，此行入道。 故云善。 为夫穿窬盗窃者，小害也。 聪智乱群者，大害也。 能除大害，小害不生，故以自愚，而除智害也。 人之难治，以其智多。 上用智，下用诈。 奸猾多端，谬妄非一。 进图荣宠，退避罪罚，网之愈密，避者愈巧。 下人有此难禁，由上用智为政也。 下四句二。 故以智治国，国之贼。 不以智治国，国之德。 夫智有二：一道智，二俗智。 道智者，心如道迹，若过以无知为上业，以无事为胜功。 俗智者，知道不足，聪察有余。 不仁之人，怀矫以求赏。 奸佞之类，用智以兆刑。 上下欺违，更相利害。 为国大贼者，用智之流也。 其不用智者，无为任物，度品愚淳，取而不污其廉，与而不至其报，下人至此，由上之德也。 下七句三。 知此两者，亦楷式。 两者，谓用智不用也。 言亦者，为上文皆云以无为理国，今复云不用智理国，故云亦。 能知用智是害国之贼，不用智是养人之德者，是为得安国修身之法式。 常知楷式，是谓玄德。 始终不改谓之常。 能知不用智，可为理国修身之法式。 始终常行而不废者，乃是合道玄之上德。 玄德深远，与物反，然后乃至大顺。 下彻曰深，傍周曰远，其德如是，谓之为玄。 道被幽明，德充宇内，谓之远矣。 凡人贵智，玄德贵愚，凡人贵积，玄德贵散，凡人从俗，玄德从道，故云反。 迹每安国利人，故云顺。 而言大顺者，上顺天道，下顺万民，在物无逆，故云大顺。 道德真经疏义卷之五竟 道德真经疏义卷之六

The root of greed lies in the desire to learn what one desires,
yet non-desire is used to guide the petty.
The scholar’s source of distinction arises from learning,
yet non-learning is used to encourage the virtuous.
To uproot the root and block the source,
then people will have no contention or theft,
no action or strife—
the world will unite in virtue,
and wealth will be held cheap while learning is abandoned—
its benefit lies here.

To aid the natural unfolding of all things
without daring to act.
Naturalness is the innate essence of things.
When desire and learning harm this essence,
removing desire and learning restores it—
thus, aiding the naturalness of all things.
When speaking of "all things," even the lifeless are included.
Human excess in desire harms oneself,
and extends harm to the lifeless.
When humans abandon desire and learning,
the essence of things remains whole.
Thus, encompassing all things.

Those who speak thus intend to save all things,
daring not to act for their own gain.

---
**Chapter Twenty-Eight of the Ancient Text**
Previously, it was made clear that action and contrivance lead to self-ruin.
Now, it is made clear that following the Dao,
abandoning cleverness and eliminating harm,
nothing arises.

Teaching through stillness,
aligning with the Mysterious Virtue—
there are three distinctions:
First, abandoning cleverness as if in foolishness,
so that errors do not arise.
Second, using cleverness without measuring gain or loss.
Third, knowing gain and loss reveals profound virtue.

Five sentences make one meaning.

The ancients who excelled in the Dao
did not seek to enlighten people—
they sought to make them foolish.
*For* (wei) means *to cultivate* (xiu).
The ancients who cultivated the Dao well
internally cultivated virtue,
concealing their brilliance and hiding their radiance,
appearing foolish.
They did not desire to reveal their clarity to others,
lest the multitude revere cleverness and wisdom,
damaging others to benefit themselves.
Those who cultivate the Dao make themselves foolish and obscure,
benefiting both self and others—
this is the path of entering the Dao.
Thus, it is said they excel.

Thieves and robbers are minor harms.
The clever disrupting the masses are major harms.
Eliminating major harms prevents minor ones from arising,
so by making oneself foolish,
cleverness’s harm is removed.

The difficulty in governing people lies in their excess cleverness.
The ruler uses cleverness, the subjects use deceit.
Deceitful cunning is manifold,
falsehoods are not singular.
They seek honor and favor in advancement,
avoiding punishment in retreat.
The more refined the nets of law,
the more cunning the evaders.
The people’s difficulty in being restrained
comes from the ruler’s use of cleverness in governance.

Thus, governing with cleverness is the state’s ruin.
Not governing with cleverness is the state’s virtue.

Cleverness has two forms:
Dao-cleverness and worldly cleverness.
Dao-cleverness is a mind aligned with the Dao’s path,
treating excess as the highest practice,
and non-action as supreme achievement.
Worldly cleverness lacks Dao-knowledge but has keen perception.
The unvirtuous harbor deceit to seek reward.
The crafty use cleverness to provoke punishment.
Above and below deceive and betray each other,
mutually harming and benefiting.
The greatest ruin of the state stems from cleverness’s influence.

Those who do not use cleverness
govern through non-action, measuring the pure and the simple,
taking without sullying integrity,
giving without demanding repayment—
when the people reach this state,
it is due to the ruler’s virtue.

Understanding these two paths
is the model.
The two paths refer to using cleverness and not using it.
Speaking of "also" (yì) refers to the preceding text,
which spoke of governing through non-action,
now reiterating "not using cleverness" to govern.
Knowing that using cleverness is the state’s ruin,
and not using cleverness is the virtue of nurturing people—
this is the method for governing the state and cultivating oneself.
Always knowing this model
is called Mysterious Virtue.
Beginning to end, without change, is called constancy.
Knowing not to use cleverness
can be the method for governing the state and cultivating oneself.
Consistently practicing it without cessation
is the supreme virtue of aligning with the Mysterious Dao.

Mysterious Virtue is profound and far-reaching,
contrary to the ways of things,
only then reaching the Great Harmony.
"Profound" speaks to its depth,
"far-reaching" to its breadth.
Its virtue is thus called Mysterious.
The Dao permeates the hidden and the manifest,
virtue fills the universe—
this is called far-reaching.

chunks.original_text: 民之轻死，以其求生之厚，是以轻死。 久遭饥寒，常忧不足，所以取不以道。 公罚私雠，养过其极，伤生损性，虽则人自轻死，终由政化使然，故知施教不可有为也。 下两句三。 夫唯无以生为者，是贤於贵生。 贤，善也。 无以生为者，谓忘生也。 多贪厚养，速致其死，唯此忘生之士，胜彼贵生之人，忘生而生存，善莫过此，故谓之贤也。 人之章第三十九 前明善解养生忘生为胜，此明欲生不死柔弱为能。 前既厚养忘生，此又坚强入死，同气相类，所以次之两别，前喻说坚强入死柔弱出生，后结说刚强不及柔弱。 五句一。 人之生柔弱，其死坚强。 生有和气，则筋骨和柔。 及其死，和气去身，则肢体坚硬。 举死对生，以明柔弱者胜，强勇者劣。 万物草木之生柔脆，其死枯槁。 言万物者，兼通有识。 人及草木，气绝体并坚强，生全形例柔弱。 此喻说也。 下六句二。 故坚强者死之徒，柔弱者生之徒。 夫坚刚之性，无往不为，或刚勇凌人，或强夺润己，志唯在得，无所怯惧，虽危必履，纵强亦凌，此谓行尸之人，与死者为类。 行柔弱者，身虽未免於死，行与长生者同，此当正说。 是以兵强则不胜，木强则共。 此举两事为证。 兵强者，众来攻之，故灭，而不胜也。 木强者，泥瓦压之，故折也。 故坚强居下，柔弱处上。 兵强者，众攻之，力强者，众伏之，故居下。 柔弱者，德之至，身危则众济，体和则众推，故处上也。 天之章第四十 前明去强取弱示是得生之方，此明举下抑高令得中道之要。 前粗后妙，所以次之四别，初举喻明道务从中适，次明天以谦益人以盈损，三明损己益物有道方能，四明圣智忘功务藏名迩。 六句一。 天之道，其犹张弓，高者抑之，下者举之，有余者损之，不足者与之。 天道玄远，人莫能知。 举喻张弓，令凡共解。 但弓之为用，贵在其调。 调与不调，张而后见，牵挽纵舍，视其调不调。 把处高抑令下，把处下举就高。 上力有余损去木，下力不足加以筋，上下均强弱等，方有弓用。 为政之法，理合如斯。 修道举真，亦当则此。 高下喻贵贱，有余不足喻贫富。 或云弛弓之时，两弰外曲，把处凸高。 张之时，则两弰内高，把处隆外。 以为高下若然者，亦如过犹不及，何则弛便面高，张则背高，终当不平，又非恒久，故未合天道。 下六句二。 天之道，损有余补不足。 人之道则不然，损不足以奉有余。 自然之理，空无所有，有余则损，似若有情，势数必然，莫知所以。 圣人以为信实，引作明戒。 人能损己有余，补人不足者，上合天道。 损人不足，奉己有余者，行人道也。 二行邪正，相去远矣。 下三句三。 孰能有余以奉天下？ 唯有道者。 谁能损己有余，以奉不足之人。 凡皆不能，唯当慈悲善人。 有道君子，方始能之。 下四句四。 是以圣人为而不恃，成功不处，其不欲见贤。 示，见也。 贤，能也。 为者则损有余者。 前劝损己济物，因恐恃功，故引圣人示其轨范，令有济物功而心不处，施为开导而德不恃者，不欲使名彰也。 高人达士，所以恶贤能之名者，一为恃德矜名，未堪入道，二为名下有利，长伪生贪，损无益有，天所诛也。 天下章第四十一 前明天道平均损多益少，此明水性柔弱利下攻强。
chunks.translated_text:
The people’s disregard for death arises from their excessive pursuit of life—
thus, they scorn death.
Long enduring hunger and cold, constantly fearing want,
they resort to means without the Dao.
Public punishments and private vengeance,
indulging beyond measure, harming life and nature—
though people may despise death themselves,
ultimately, it is governance and teaching that drive them thus.
Hence, it is known that imparting instruction must not be coercive.

Two sentences below, three in meaning.

Only those who do not cling to life are wiser than those who prize it.
*"Wise"* means *"good."*
Those who do not cling to life are those who forget life.
Excessive greed for nourishment swiftly leads to death—
only those who forget life surpass those who cling to life.
To forget life while living is the greatest good—
thus, they are called *"wise."*

**Chapter Thirty-Nine of Human Nature**
Previously, it was shown that resolving to live while forgetting life is superior;
now, it is shown that desiring life and avoiding death through gentleness is skillful.
Having already spoken of excessive nourishment and forgetting life,
now it speaks of firmness and entering death—
both share the same *qi*, hence the two distinctions follow.
The first uses analogy to explain firmness and entering death, gentleness and living,
while the second concludes that the rigid do not surpass the gentle.

Five sentences, one meaning.

Human life is gentle and weak,
but death is firm and strong.
Life possesses harmonious *qi*, then sinews and bones are supple and yielding.
When death comes, harmonious *qi* departs the body,
and limbs become rigid and hard.
By contrasting death with life, it is shown that the gentle prevail,
while the strong and bold are inferior.
All things—grasses and trees—
in life are gentle and fragile,
but in death, they wither and stiffen.
Speaking of *"all things"* encompasses both sentient and insentient.
Humans and grasses alike, when *qi* is severed, their forms become firm and strong,
while in life, their forms are entirely gentle and weak.
This is an illustrative analogy.

Six sentences, two meanings.

Thus, the firm and strong are of death’s kind,
while the gentle and weak are of life’s kind.
The nature of rigidity and harshness
goes wherever it will—
some are bold and domineering over others,
some forcibly seize what they desire,
their will fixed on gain, fearless of danger.
Though perilous, they press forward;
though strong, they still overreach—
these are called *"walking corpses,"*
akin to the dead.

The gentle and weak, though death may not spare them,
walk as those who seek longevity do—
this is the proper teaching.
Thus, the strong in arms are not victorious,
the strong in wood are split.
These two examples serve as proof.
The strong in arms: when many attack, they are annihilated and do not prevail.
The strong in wood: when pressed by clay and tiles, they break.
Hence, the rigid and strong are beneath,
while the gentle and weak are above.
The strong in arms: when many attack, they are subdued by strength,
while the gentle and weak: when in peril, others aid them;
when harmonious, others uphold them—
thus, they are above.

**Chapter Forty of Heaven’s Nature**
Previously, it was shown that discarding strength and embracing weakness is the way to life;
now, it is shown that suppressing the high and elevating the low
to attain the middle path is essential.
The first is crude, the second refined—
hence, the four distinctions follow:
first, using analogy to show that the Dao seeks the balanced middle;
second, that Heaven benefits through humility while humans benefit through excess and deficiency;
third, that only through methodical self-abnegation and benefiting others can one achieve it;
fourth, that the sage’s wisdom forgets merit and conceals virtue.

Six sentences, one meaning.

Heaven’s Way is like drawing a bow:
the high are lowered, the low are raised,
the excessive are diminished, the deficient are supplemented.
Heaven’s principles are profound and distant—
no one can fathom them.
The analogy of the bow is given
to make it comprehensible to all.
Yet the bow’s true purpose lies in its tuning.
Whether tuned or not is only seen when drawn—
pulling, releasing, loosening—
observing whether it is tuned or not.
When the grip is high, it lowers the bow;
when the grip is low, it raises it.
If the upper strength is excessive, wood is removed;
if the lower strength is insufficient, sinew is added.
When the upper and lower strengths are balanced—
equal in firmness and weakness—
only then does the bow serve its purpose.
The principles of governance must align thus.
Cultivating the Dao and attaining authenticity
should also follow this.

*"High"* and *"low"* refer to *"noble"* and *"base,"*
*"excessive"* and *"deficient"* refer to *"wealthy"* and *"poor."*
Some say that when the bow is slack,
the two ends curve outward, and the grip is convex and high.
When drawn, the two ends curve inward, and the grip bulges outward.
If *"high"* and *"low"* are thus,
it is like exceeding or falling short—
why? When slack, the face is high;
when drawn, the back is high—
yet it is never truly level,
nor is it enduring.
Thus, it does not accord with Heaven’s Way.

Six sentences, two meanings.

Heaven’s Way is to diminish the excessive and supplement the deficient.
Human conduct is otherwise:
they diminish the deficient to serve the excessive.
Natural principle is empty and without possession—
when there is excess, it is diminished;
it seems as if it has sentiment,
yet fate and necessity compel it—
no one knows why.
The sage takes this as truth,
using it as a clear warning.
If a person can diminish their own excess
to supplement others’ deficiencies,
they align with Heaven’s Way.
If they diminish others’ deficiencies
to serve their own excess,
they follow human conduct.
The distance between these two paths—
one corrupt, one virtuous—
is vast.

Three sentences, three meanings.

Who can have excess to bestow upon the world?
Only the Daoist.
Who can diminish their own excess
to supplement those in want?
None but the benevolent and virtuous.
Only the sagely and virtuous can achieve this.

Four sentences, four meanings.

Thus, the sage acts without relying on it,
achieves success without dwelling on it,
and does not desire to be seen as virtuous.
*"Demonstrate"* means *"to be seen."*
*"Virtuous"* means *"able."*
The sage diminishes the excessive—
previously encouraging self-abnegation to aid others,
fearing they might rely on their deeds,
thus citing the sage’s model:
though they open the way and guide with virtue,
they do not claim merit.
High-minded and accomplished individuals
despise the reputation of virtue
for two reasons:
first, relying on virtue and boasting of ability
is unworthy of the Dao;
second, fame brings gain,
fostering deceit and greed—
taking from those without benefit,
a sin Heaven punishes.

**Chapter Forty-One of the World’s Nature**
Previously, it was shown that Heaven’s Way balances excess and deficiency;
now, it is shown that water’s gentle and weak nature
attacks the strong from below.

chunks.original_text: 非刚是柔，义味为次有三别，初明以柔破刚在用无易，次明理事昭朗人不知行，后明容非致福愚人不信。 五句一。 天下柔弱莫过於水， 万物之中，至柔至弱者，无过於水。 此明水体，使为道者法之。 而攻坚强者莫之能胜，其无以易之。 坚强者，山石之类。 水之为用，穴石崩山，余物不及。 体则无累，用则有功。 体用两能，在物无易，此明用也。 在人坚强者，烦恼也。 柔弱者，道心也。 欲破烦恼，唯有道心能之，不可以他物代易。 下四句二。 故柔胜刚，弱胜强，天下莫能知，莫能行。 刚谓烦恼，为道心所销，故心胜也。 人我强梁，被柔弱之行摧伏，故强劣也。 此皆目验可见，众不能知者，愚也。 或有知而不能者，无信心也。 下六句三。 是以圣人言：受国之垢，是谓社稷主。 受国不祥，是谓天下王。 老君引古圣法言以劝今，垢谓恶言谤讟，不祥谓非罪加身，则万方有过，在余一人是也。 为下柔弱，志在谦虚，而能容受垢谤，故得位居公侯，为社稷之主。 能受不祥，其德弥大，得为皇王帝主。 六合钦风，其道学之流，虚怀若谷，近为人天化主，远则真圣法王。 正言若反。 向说柔弱攻坚受垢而为王者，皆是合道。 正言信实非谬，但为常流所闻，将似反俗。 和大章第四十二 前明化用柔弱忍垢为王，此明王德无为大怨不起。 前既物归，后须养物，章中三别，初明有怨能和未若令怨不起，次明行道如契怨自不生，后明天道无亲终符有善。 三句一。 和大怨，必有余怨，安可以为善？ 和，犹消停也。 大怨，被杀伤也。 衣食足知礼节，彼此有怨，良为不足，不足则偷夺杀伤，怨怨相次，怨怀雪耻，必图报复，杀期誓得以快其心，使甘辞善说暂得和销，怨报不行，怨心犹在。 夫此怨虽息，后怨更起，天下至广，怨雠巨多。 欲使善辩之流，家到户至，以此和释，何可为善。 若令天下大同，则无怨可和，此为善也。 然唯明主之德，能乎其有，修身者欲出生死宿怨患累，新染者必须心处无为，身行无事，则得本怨永断，余怨不作，用此和怨，可谓善矣。 下五句二。 是以圣人执左契，而不责於人。 契，信也。 古者未有文字，刻木为契，雄雌两合，左雄君执，右雌臣执，用为政化。 其法若当，则天下如一，彼信此信，秤斗不行，人亲我亲，爱敬无二。 强不陵弱，贵不欺贱，则何以生。 故明王之在上，要观风俗，人有斗争，察其所由，知从上来，革其契令，罪在於己，不责於人。 言人者则有大怨者也。 身自修行者，以道养生，无为保性，人有怨己，但自责躬，不敢怨天尤人，傍及神鬼。 故有德司契，无德司彻。 彻，犹失也。 有德之君，见人有过，但自伺察，己法不当，而不罪责於人。 无德之主，唯知伺人过失，不知人过之由己，故罪责於人，而不责己。 下两句三。 天道无亲，常与善人。 天，自然也。 无亲，谓平等也。 善人则通及君臣万姓。 人能有过责己，虚淡无为，则自然之道与己符合，虽则执左契，如契得无怨。 未若行大道者，不立契而无怨，且鬼神暗伏，况人伦乎。 小国章第四十三 前明善与道同人无怨争，此明君与臣合上下无为。 前犹执契销怨，此便有法不用，从粗至妙，所以次之三别，初明君臣有道人物安全，次明人安所居乐道知足，后明相忘道术不事往来。
chunks.translated_text:
**Chapter Forty-Two of the Great Harmony**
Previously, it was shown that the Way’s transformation and application lie in gentle and weak endurance of defamation to become a ruler—
all these are in accordance with the Dao.
True words are like their opposites.

**Chapter Forty-Three of the Small Realm**
Previously, it was shown that goodness aligns with the Dao and that people harbor no grudges.
Now, it is shown that the ruler and ministers unite in harmony,
with no need for action above or below.

*"Gentle"* is not *"rigid,"* and *"virtuous"* is secondary to three distinctions:
first, gentle overcoming strength is effortless in application;
second, principles and affairs are clear, yet people fail to act accordingly;
third, tolerating defamation brings blessings, yet the foolish do not believe.

**Five Sentences, One Meaning:**
Among all things in the world, none are as gentle and weak as water.
Within all things, the most gentle and weak are none other than water.
This illustrates water’s essence,
so that those who follow the Dao may take it as their model.
Yet in overcoming strength and rigidity,
nothing can surpass it—
its power is unchanging.
Strength and rigidity are like mountains and stones.
Water’s use: it erodes stone, topples mountains,
while other things cannot compare.
In essence, it bears no burden;
in application, it achieves great results.
Essence and application both excel—
in things, its power is unchanging;
this illustrates its application.
In humans, strength and rigidity are afflictions;
gentle and weak are the Dao-heart.
To overcome afflictions,
only the Dao-heart can do so—
no other thing can replace it.

**Four Sentences, Two Meanings:**
Thus, gentle overcomes rigid,
weak overcomes strong—
yet none in the world can know or act upon this.
Rigid refers to afflictions,
which are extinguished by the Dao-heart,
so the heart prevails.
Human arrogance and obstinacy
are subdued by gentle and weak conduct,
so strength is inferior.
All this is verifiable by sight—
yet those who cannot know are foolish.
Or those who know but cannot act—
they lack faith in the Dao.

**Six Sentences, Three Meanings:**
Hence, the sage says:
*"To bear a nation’s defamation,
this is called the sovereign of the land and grain."*
*"To bear a nation’s ill fortune,
this is called the ruler of all under Heaven."*
The Old Master cites ancient sage laws
to exhort the present:
defamation refers to slanderous words and calumny,
ill fortune refers to unjust suffering—
then all directions have faults,
while the blame rests solely on me.
To be gentle and weak below,
with a mind set on humility,
yet able to endure defamation,
one attains the rank of a public duke,
becoming the sovereign of the land and grain.
To bear ill fortune,
one’s virtue is even greater—
thus one becomes an emperor and sovereign ruler.
All under Heaven reveres the wind of virtue;
this is the flow of the sage’s Way.
With a heart as vast as a valley,
nearby, one becomes a transformative sage for humans and Heaven;
farther, one becomes the true sovereign of the law.

True words appear as their opposites.
Earlier, it was said that gentle and weak overcoming strength,
enduring defamation to become a ruler—
all these are in accordance with the Dao.
True words are sincere and not false,
yet to the common masses they seem contrary to convention.

---

**Chapter Forty-Two of the Great Harmony**
Previously, it was shown that the Way’s transformation and application lie in gentle and weak endurance of defamation to become a ruler—
all these are in accordance with the Dao.
Now, it is shown that the ruler’s virtue lies in non-action,
not provoking grudges.

**Three Sentences, One Meaning:**
To reconcile great grudges,
there must still be lingering grudges—
how can this be considered good?
*"Reconcile"* means *"to pacify and settle."*
Great grudges are those where one has been killed or injured.
When clothing and food are sufficient and rites and propriety are known,
people still harbor grudges—
this is truly insufficient.
Insufficiency leads to theft, plunder, killing, and injury;
grudges follow in succession.
With resentment and shame unresolved,
one must seek revenge,
swearing to kill to satisfy one’s heart.
Even if one sweetly speaks and acts with good intentions,
temporarily achieving reconciliation,
the grudge remains unfulfilled,
and the heart still harbors resentment.
Though this grudge may subside,
another will arise.
The world is vast,
and grudges and enmities are boundless.
To make those skilled in persuasion
travel from house to house,
using this method to reconcile grudges—
how can this be considered good?
If one achieves great harmony under Heaven,
then there are no grudges to reconcile—
this is true goodness.
Yet only the enlightened ruler’s virtue
can bring this about.
Those who cultivate themselves
wish to sever the cycle of birth and death,
freeing themselves from past grudges and afflictions.
Those newly tainted
must settle their minds in non-action,
conduct their bodies in non-doing—
then they attain the root of grudges permanently severed,
and no further grudges arise.
Using this to reconcile grudges,
one can truly be called good.

**Five Sentences, Two Meanings:**
Thus, the sage holds the left token
and does not blame others.
The token symbolizes *"trust."*
In ancient times, before writing existed,
people carved wooden tokens for agreements.
Male and female tokens fit together—
the left (male) token was held by the lord,
the right (female) token by the subject,
used for governance and transformation.
If their laws are just,
then all under Heaven will be as one—
trusting each other,
scales and measures will not be needed,
and love and respect will be equal.
The strong will not oppress the weak,
the noble will not bully the humble—
then how can grudges arise?
Hence, the enlightened ruler above
must observe the customs of the people.
If there are disputes and conflicts,
investigate their origins—
if they stem from above,
abolish the token decrees.
If the fault lies with oneself,
one does not blame others.
This is speaking of those who harbor great grudges.
If one cultivates oneself through practice,
nourishing life with the Dao,
preserving nature through non-action,
and others hold grudges against me,
I only blame myself—
not daring to blame Heaven, people, or gods and spirits.
Thus, the virtuous hold the token,
while the unvirtuous lose it.
*"Lose"* means *"to fail."* The virtuous ruler,
seeing others’ faults,
only reflects on himself—
*"My laws are not appropriate,"*
and does not punish or blame others.
The unvirtueful ruler
only knows to spy on others’ mistakes,
unaware that others’ faults originate from himself—
thus he punishes and blames others,
while not blaming himself.

**Two Sentences, Three Meanings:**
The Way of Heaven has no favorites,
always aligning with the virtuous.
*"Heaven"* means *"the natural order."*
*"No favorites"* means *"equality."*
The virtuous include all—
rulers, subjects, and the common folk.
If one can take responsibility for their own faults,
be humble and detached in non-action,
then the natural order will align with them—
though they hold the left token,
their agreements will be without grudges.
Better still is one who walks the great Dao—
no tokens are needed, yet grudges do not arise.
Even spirits and gods remain hidden;
how much more so among human relations?

---

**Chapter Forty-Three of the Small Realm**
Previously, it was shown that goodness aligns with the Dao,
and that people harbor no grudges.
Now, it is shown that the ruler and ministers unite,
with no need for action above or below.

**Three Sentences, One Meaning:**
Rulers and ministers, if they follow the Dao,
will ensure safety for the people.
People are content in their dwellings,
knowing the joy of the Dao,
content with sufficiency.
Rulers and ministers forget each other,
practicing the Dao—
no need for visits or exchanges.

Previously, it was shown that Heaven’s Way balances excess and deficiency;

chunks.original_text: 六句一。 小国寡民，使有什伯之器而不用。 土境不宽，名为小国。 士庶盖少，名曰寡民。 为能行道，家富人足。 什伯者，家具杂物之大数，或什或伯。 物皆备有，无为省事，故不用之。 修身者，国身也，人六识也，言寡小者谦也。 什伯之器谓伎术，伎术可用，故云器。 言不用者，为虚忘也。 使民重死，而不远徙。 君上有道，使人欣生恶死，以死为难重，故不轻入死地。 周身自足，无烦厚积，故不远徙他、乡营求分外。 若心王有道，神识恬和，无欲无求，恶销累尽，平生小过，尚不轻犯，况死事若重，辄肯身为。 虽有舟舆，无所乘之。 虽有甲兵，无所陈之。
chunks.translated_text:
**Six Sentences, One Meaning:**

The Small Realm, few in its people,
commands them to possess tenfold or hundredfold implements yet not employ them.
Its lands are narrow, hence called the Small Realm;
Its commoners and scholars are few, hence called few in its people.
This is because one can walk the Dao—
households are rich, the people content.
*Tenfold* and *hundredfold* refer to the great numbers of household goods;
all things are fully provided, yet simplicity saves effort—
thus they are not used.
*Moderation* is the Dao of the realm,
and the people’s six senses—
to speak of fewness and smallness is humility.

When it speaks of *tenfold* and *hundredfold implements*,
it means arts and crafts—
arts and crafts can be employed, hence called *implements*.
To say *not employed* is to say they are forgotten in emptiness.

Let the people hold death as weighty,
yet not flee to distant lands.
When the ruler walks the Dao,
the people rejoice in life yet dread death—
death is hard to bear, hence they do not lightly enter perilous ground.
Their bodies are self-sufficient,
free from laborious hoarding—
thus they do not wander far or scheme for external gains.
If the heart-mind’s king walks the Dao,
the senses and consciousness are tranquil and harmonious,
with no cravings, no demands—
evil is dispelled, burdens vanish,
and even minor offenses in life are not lightly committed,
how much more so death?
Though chariots and boats exist,
they find no use for them.
Though armor and weapons are kept,
they find no need to display them.

chunks.original_text: 舟舆则什伯器具之首。 举大言之，但云四事。 舟运於水，舆载於陆，既为道足於身，财足於家，无所须求，故不乘也。 甲谓介冑，将被身首，以御外敌。 兵者戈锋，手持以斫剌。 亦云兵中精最者谓之甲兵。 修身者昔时情识刚勇如兵，今汨柔挺委顺若水，唯希利物，不欲损人，仪相则有，施用则无，故虽有而无所陈也。 使民复结绳而用之。 复，反本也。 结绳谓淳古之政也。 以时言之，则古淳而今浇。 就心言之，则道心淳而俗心浇。 原其始也。 心欲萌生则变淳为浇，心除贪嗜则变浇为淳。 此则时之浇淳随心变易，如四夫淳素，唯资一身，无能易俗，若使天下还淳，时同上古，要待有道之主，方始得之。 下四句二。 甘其食，美其服，安其居，乐其俗。 心无嗜俗，蔬食自甘。 志唯俭素，裘褐为美。 所居得悦、蓬庐足安，乐道无为，岂间风俗。 下四句三。 邻国相望，鸡狗之声相闻，使民至老不相往来。 邻国相望，为国小相近，故目望所及，晨鸡夜狗相闻，明其不远。 从小至老，经时已久，不相往来，由其各足。 道足则无所谘询，财足则不须借贷，至足相忘，故不来往也。 信言章第四十四 《道德二经》八十一章，初既开宗，中间广说，此章居后，理当结会，结束诸义，同会一源。 就此章中四科结释，初结一切言教简别真伪，次结诸学人甄明得失，三结上德圣人财法无积，四结天圣二道通明人法诸义。 两句一。 信言不美，美言不信。 信实之言谓名教也。 夫《经》法所言，当理直说，词质义举，而无虚饬美艳，无隐无曲，易知易行，此直《经》也。 巧说美言，绮饰词句，虚陈祸福，引诱贪愚，虽来浅俗，更迷深理，此则有华无实，非真《经》也。 以此信美二文，通辩一切名教真伪 下四句二。 善者不辩，辩者不善。 知言内心，善言外行，心知身行，不分辩己，知斥异众人者，真善人也。 若自辩己是，唯事非他，以利口屈人，以多言伏物者，非善人也。 此六句通论学人得失，人法真伪，求诸精最，龟镜在斯，幸遇同心，庶留明鉴。 下三句三。 知者不博、博者不知。 能知道者，知道非言，则不可以多言。 博识取知，则为博溺，心翻更迷惑，故言不知。 此则为知，故不博。 为博，故不知。 圣人不积。 积，藏蓄也。 积有二义：一积德，二不积。 树德立功，积而又积，所谓重积德也。 不积者有德教愚，有财施贫，机有堪授，己无所惜，积言自修，不积言利物。 既以为民，己愈有。 既，尽也。 为，施教也。 愈，益也。 圣人有德，无所吝惜，尽以教人，施为教方，随机利物。 前人受润，圣德日新，故云愈有。 既以与民，己愈多。 以财施贫己益丰，有法无状象，至精至微，唯可心神冥会，不可持捉，故言为也。 财是形质，可以手度，故言与也。 下四句四。 天之道，利而不害。 天道即自然之道也。 言其体也，空无所有，神妙恍惚。 语其用也，无所不生，无所不成。
chunks.translated_text:
「Chariots and boats rank first among myriad implements.
In grand discourse, only the four matters are mentioned.
Boats traverse the waters, carriages bear the land—
when the Dao suffices for the body,
and wealth suffices for the home,
there is no need for further seeking,
so they are not employed.

*Armour* refers to protective gear,
to be worn on the body and head,
to repel external foes.
*Weapons* are spears and blades,
held in hand to strike and slash.
Yet the finest of weapons are called *armour*.
In cultivating the self, the ancient heart-mind was fierce and bold as weapons,
but now it is gentle and yielding, compliant and serene as water—
seeking only to benefit others,
not desiring to harm.
Their outward forms may exist,
but their application is none,
so though present, they are not displayed.

Let the people return to the governance of knotted cords.
*Return* means to revert to origins.
*Knotted cords* symbolize the pure politics of antiquity.
In terms of time, the ancient was pure while the present is corrupt.
In terms of the heart, the Dao-heart is pure while the vulgar heart is corrupt.
At their inception, when the heart-mind’s desires first sprout,
it shifts from purity to corruption.
When the heart-mind discards greed and craving,
it shifts from corruption back to purity.
Thus, the corruption or purity of time follows the heart-mind’s transformation,
like the Four Husbands’ pure simplicity—
it depends solely on one’s own cultivation,
not on altering the world’s customs.
If one wishes to restore the world to purity,
to match the age of antiquity,
it must await a ruler who walks the Dao.

The next four sentences are the second category:
Let their food be savoury,
their clothing be fine,
their dwellings be secure,
and their customs be joyous.
With no cravings for worldly tastes,
plain food is naturally sweet.
With only modest desires,
rough garments are deemed splendid.
When their abode is pleasing—
even a thatched hut suffices for comfort—
and they take delight in the Dao’s effortless Way,
what need have they for changing customs?

The following four sentences are the third category:
Neighbouring lands are visible,
and the sounds of roosters and dogs are heard between them,
yet the people do not visit one another until old age.
*Neighbouring lands* are small nations close at hand,
so that what the eye can see includes morning roosters and nighttime dogs,
making it clear they are not distant.
From childhood to old age,
spanning long years,
they do not come and go—
because each suffices in their own right.
When the Dao suffices, there is no need for consultation,
when wealth suffices, there is no need for borrowing or lending,
and mutual sufficiency leads to forgetting one another,
so they do not visit.

The next six sentences are the fourth category:
*True words are not ornate; ornate words are not true.*
*True words* refer to the teachings of the Dao.
The *Scriptures*’ teachings should be spoken directly,
plain in language yet profound in meaning,
without embellishment or allure,
without concealment or distortion—
easy to know, easy to practice.
This is the *direct Scripture*.
Crafty, ornate speech,
adorned with flowery words,
hollowly proclaiming blessings and calamities,
to seduce the greedy and mislead the foolish—
though it may appeal to the shallow,
it further confuses the profound.
Such is superficial without substance,
not the true *Scripture*.
With these two distinctions—*true* and *ornate*—
all teachings of the Dao can be judged for authenticity or falsity.

*Good persons do not argue; arguers are not good.*
Knowledge of words lies in the heart,
goodness of words lies in practice—
when the heart knows and the body acts,
there is no need to argue for oneself.
The true good person rejects what others deem wrong.
If one argues only for oneself,
condemning others while flattering the crowd,
using eloquence to bend others,
and many words to subdue things—
this is not the good person.
These six sentences universally discuss the merits and faults of scholars,
the authenticity or falsity of teachings,
and seek the most refined—
the tortoise-shell mirror lies here.
Fortunate are those who meet with like-minded hearts,
to leave behind a clear reflection for future generations.

*The wise are not versed in many things; versed ones are not wise.*
Those who truly grasp the Dao
know the Dao is not conveyed through words,
so they do not rely on excessive speech.
To amass knowledge and claim wisdom
is to drown in superficiality,
to further bewilder the heart-mind—
thus, they are said to be *unwise*.
This is *wisdom*, so they are not *versed*.
To be *versed*, they are *unwise*.
The Sage does not hoard.
*Hoard* means to store and accumulate.
There are two meanings of *hoard*:
one is to accumulate virtue,
the other is not to accumulate.

To cultivate virtue and establish merit,
layer upon layer, as in *repeatedly accumulating virtue*.
Not to accumulate means to bestow virtue upon the foolish,
to give wealth to the poor—
when the opportunity arises, to teach without hesitation,
to spare nothing of oneself.
To accumulate speech in self-cultivation,
but not to accumulate speech for others’ benefit.
Having served the people,
one’s own virtue grows ever more abundant.
*Having* means to exhaust,
*serve* means to teach and guide,
*abundant* means to increase.
The Sage’s virtue is boundless,
without stinginess or reluctance—
exhausted in teaching others,
guiding them through practice,
and benefiting them according to their capacity.
The recipients grow enriched,
and the Sage’s virtue renews itself daily—
thus it is said to *increase*.
Having given to the people,
one’s own virtue becomes even greater.
Wealth is given to the poor,
and one’s own abundance grows richer—
the Dao has no outward form,
so subtle and profound it can only be grasped by the heart-mind’s silent communion,
not by physical holding or seizing—
thus it is called *serve*.
Wealth is tangible and measurable,
so it is called *give*.

The Way of Heaven,
benefits yet does not harm.
The *Way of Heaven* is the Way of Nature.
In speaking of its essence,
it is empty, yet all-pervading—
divine and elusive.
In speaking of its function,
it gives rise to all things,
and brings all things to fruition.»

chunks.original_text: 此为利普，终无损害。 圣人之道，为而不争。 圣人者，无为上德也。 圣教微言，务存虚己，为而不恃，功必推人。 让犹不取，於事何争，利则益物，为则有功。 功益无争，虚忘之极，妙与道合，德之至也。 夫心口者，争之具也。 天道圣德，混沌玄同，万物生成，事由天圣，非天不生，非圣不成。 故天道无言，广利生蓄，视同刍狗，终无损害。 圣有心口，而与好争者同。 然则同其相，异其用，故同心口而有教，异心口而无争。 既有天圣名殊，须陈争害迹异，故天言无害，圣言无争。 若以玄同言之，天道自无争，圣道亦无害，应迹设教，故有二名。 损教归理，寂无天圣，天圣之本，既曰无矣。 争害之进，岂有异乎。 一部妙《经》，事终於此，随立随遣者，意在忘言会道。 故以此章结遣五千奥旨，斯意若得，则何言不通。 夫道者，遍覃诸有，即有求之，终莫能得。 有物之外，非则无道。 离物求之，又无得法。 信知道无不在，所在皆无。 欲有真求，无论方所。 比见诸家注解，多依事物，以文属身，则节解之意也。 飞炼上药，《丹经》之祖也。 远说虚无，王弼之类也。 以事明理，孙登之辈也。 存诸法象，阴阳之流也。 安存戒亡，韩非之喻也。 溺心灭质，严遵之博也。 加文取悟，儒学之宗也。 又俗流系有，非老绝於圣智； 僧辈因空，嗤李被於家国。 良由孔乏采真之务，释无诠道之功，徒使竭性力而扬后名，罄珍资而市来福。 所以坐三隅而自是，擅一曲而暧昧，长迷大道，终天致惑，斯并争探理，窟角辩虚，玄正辟行，心傍一亏理物然。 此《经》洪源深广，随用精粗，亦犹大鸟冲天，遐迩同望，远睹如燕，近见如鸿，北人视之以为南，南方观之以为北，心心既异，造适遂殊，今则思去物华，念归我实，道资身得，隳体坐忘，修之有恒，稍觉良益。 故知不龟手之药，是一漂絮裂地之殊信哉。 道德真经疏义卷之六竟
chunks.translated_text:
This is the Way of universal benefit,
yet never causing loss.
The Sage’s Dao is to act without striving.
The Sage’s teaching is in subtle words,
seeking only to preserve the empty self—
acting yet not claiming credit,
always attributing merit to others.
If one does not take, how can one contend?
If one benefits, how can one compete?
Merit and benefit without contention—
the ultimate of self-forgetting,
the marvelous harmony with the Dao,
the peak of virtue.

The heart and mouth are the tools of contention.
The Dao of Heaven and the Sage’s virtue
are indistinct and profound in unity.
All things arise and reach fulfillment
through the interplay of Heaven and Sagehood—
without Heaven, nothing is born;
without the Sage, nothing is perfected.
Hence, the Dao of Heaven speaks without harm,
while the Sage’s words avoid contention.
Yet though their names differ,
their essence is one:
Heaven’s speech causes no harm,
the Sage’s words provoke no strife.
If spoken of as indistinct unity,
then Heaven’s Dao has no contention,
and the Sage’s Way causes no harm—
yet they are distinguished by their teachings,
thus bearing two names.

To abandon teachings and return to principle,
to rest in the silent unity of Heaven and Sagehood—
the root of Heaven and Sagehood is already "none."
The progression of contention and harm
has no difference at all.
A single wondrous *Sutra*,
its meaning concludes here.
Those who establish and then discard
do so to forget words and grasp the Dao.

Thus, this chapter encapsulates the five thousand profound truths,
and if its intent is understood,
what words remain unclear?

The Dao pervades all existence—
yet if one seeks it within existence,
one will never find it.
Beyond existence, it is nonexistent.
If one seeks it apart from existence,
there is no method to attain it.
The faithful know that the Dao is without absence,
yet wherever it is present, it is without form.
To truly seek the Dao,
one must disregard all distinctions of place and direction.

Many household interpretations explain it through worldly affairs,
attaching words to the body—
this is the meaning of "node" (节).
Alchemical refinement of the highest medicines—
the origin of the *Dan Jing*.
Distant talk of emptiness—
the style of Wang Bi.
Illustrating principle through affairs—
the manner of Sun Login.
Preserving all phenomena—
the tradition of Yin-Yang.
Peaceful dwelling yet abandoning restraint—
the metaphor of Han Fei.
Drowning the mind to extinguish form—
the expansive method of Yan Zun.
Adding words to gain enlightenment—
the core of Confucian learning.

The vulgar cling to existence,
failing to grasp the Dao’s absolute wisdom;
The monks adhere to emptiness,
deriding Li Ji’s teachings as mere household matters.
This is because Confucius lacked the pursuit of true essence,
and the Buddha had no skill in elucidating the Dao—
both merely exhausted their vitality to earn later fame,
and drained their precious resources to seek transient fortune.

Thus, they sit in three corners and insist on their own correctness,
or monopolize a single tune and speak in riddles,
prolonging their confusion of the Great Dao,
until death they remain perplexed—
all are caught in contention over principle,
digging into corners to debate emptiness,
splitting the profound and true,
and their minds lean ever so slightly from the Dao.

This *Sutra*’s vast source is deep and broad,
its applications ranging from refined to coarse—
like a great bird soaring to the heavens,
seen from afar as a swallow, up close as a crane,
northerners behold it as southern,
southerners perceive it as northern.
Since minds differ,
their interpretations vary.
Now, we strive to transcend material adornments,
to focus on our own true essence.
The Dao is obtained through the body,
yet to attain it, one must demolish form and sit in forgetfulness,
pursuing it with constancy,
gradually feeling its profound benefits.

Thus, we know that the medicine which does not cause calloused hands
is but a floating wisp of cotton,
a mere shred of earthly deception—
how strange and false!

*The True Classic of Dao and Virtue*—
Exhaustive Exegesis, Volume Six concludes.

the Dao has no outward form,
so subtle and profound it can only be grasped by the heart-mind’s silent communion,
not by physical holding or seizing—
thus it is called *serve*.
Wealth is tangible and measurable,
so it is called *give*.

The Way of Heaven,
benefits yet does not harm.
The *Way of Heaven* is the Way of Nature.
In speaking of its essence,
it is empty, yet all-pervading—
divine and elusive.
In speaking of its function,
it gives rise to all things,
and brings all things to fruition.»
